ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Became more comfortable reading sociological texts.
learned how to analyze and explore sociological arguments

This class traced modernity through different motifs and theories in sociology. I learned about how modernity has manifested itself as social, political, economic, and environmental violence throughout the world. I learned about the intersections of class, race, and gender with modernity.
A systematic overview of the sociological modernity and civilization progression
A wide array of sociological theory
The background information of prominent sociological works regarding modernity and civilization!
I developed a deeper thinking into texts the were centered around philosophy, capitalism, and gender that gave a new light on how others (including me view the world).

This course provided a variety of perspectives on recent and historical transitions to modernity from a sociological perspective. It developed skills of reading, analysis, synthesis, and discussion, and gave a number of fascinating ways to approach questions of modernity through a wide socio-cultural lens.
This course involved readings that we analyzed in the context of defining qualities of being "modern."
Fascinating analysis of modernity and the civilizing process
i learned a great deal of the development of societies across various countries and how they related or compared to the united states

I learned a lot about civilization building, different theories of government, and how sociologists view our world.  I also learned to observe my world in a way similar to our readings, and I questioned a lot of things I hadn't thought about before.
I learned basic themes in sociology, how to read classic sociological works, and how to interpret these theories and apply them to modern life.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course covers a lot of material, which makes it both intellectually stimulating but also gives you a lot of reading. I think the blog post format works really well, but I wish that our class was smaller so that we could have less mediated discussions.
I enjoyed the discussion format.
well structured course, sometimes the discussion would be hampered by a massive queue which disjointed the conversation. but it was very inclusive, interesting, and enjoyable class meetings

it was a great course. I really liked that the reading schedule was based on week rather than on every class meeting. I really liked the course blog format and the agency we had in deciding our final project.

Strength:
the in class discussions themselves

Weaknesses:
-The format of the in class discussions. Because the class had ~25-30 we had to form a queue in zoom chat to speak. Oftentimes it would take 15 minutes before you got your chance to speak so it never felt like a class discussion but rather everyone fighting to make their point for their participation grade.
-You don't really know you're grade until after you turn in your final paper.  
-The course blog site is awful from a technical standpoint. Please use another website. 
-An insane amount of reading. You don't really know what you have to read until Wednesday lecture. Then you have to finish your reading to make a blog post by Sunday. You essentially get 4 days to read 100-300 pages (sometimes a full book). Realistically, people just aren't going to do all that within such a short timeframe which leads to surface level discussions.
Awesome course, understanding instructor. Really interesting and engaging course material which clearly shows greater learning goals for the course!

It would be helpful to get more feedback on blog posts and responses (at least for lead blog posts) both to improve our writing/engagement with the material/etc and to have a sense of how we're doing in the class.

I found that most of the time the ideas and thoughts of other students would be so unnecessarily long and confusing while also including paragraphs with and overwhelming amount of academic jargon  that it made it difficult to actually understand what the class was talking about. While we were dealing with heavy text, no one in the class wanted to actually simply it, except Prof. Adams.

This course benefited from a great reading list and class structure, and the creative use of a course website which served as a platform for student thought and discussion. One way the course could be improved is by either limiting the amount of students to a more conventional seminar size, or shifting from a discussion format to a more lecture-based structure that could accommodate more students.
I found the structure of the discussions to work very well and generate fluent and interesting discourse. Obviously, having in-person discussions would be better than via zoom.
Professor Adams is wonderful and has curated an unbelievable list of readings. The discussions are so engaging and the format is engaging but not stressful.
The course was very strong.
this course was extremely engaging i loved the class discussions that took place every class

Strengths: This was such a good class.  Prof. Adams was so kind, caring, and understanding of the fact that we were living through a pandemic.  All of our discussions were really interesting, and I was always excited to do the readings.  I loved how open and flexible the discussion was, and having students lead each week was a really good idea since I got to see how my classmates interpreted the readings as well.
Weaknesses: Honestly, there are not many weaknesses of this course.  Sometimes it felt a little intimidating to participate because the class size was bigger than a normal seminar, but the comment-chat system worked well.  I would say that the weaknesses of this class were due to the limitations of Zoom/online school, not the class itself.

This is an absolutely incredible course. Professor Adams is brilliant, warm, and engaging, understanding of student time and challenges, patient, and flexible. I was originally skeptical of the class format, which is like a seminar, but with close to 30 students. However, Professor Adams runs the class in a way that enables all students to get a chance to share, while still leaving time to unpack the theories we discuss. She strikes a wonderful balance between free flowing class discussion and ensuring that the major points of the theories did not go undetected. The reading load is manageable and the final project provides flexibility for students to engage with the parts of the course they enjoyed most. My favorite parts of classes were her brief summaries and the questions she posed to the class-- I think the only possible improvement would be for her to spend a little bit of time summarizing the main points or asking some questions that ensured students pulled out the most important parts of the theories at the end/middle of class, not just at the beginning.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Online discussion forums were nice.
all tenets of virtual learning succeeded
This class transferred well to the Zoom discussion format.
Made a course blog which got the students engaged in discussion in AND out of class.

The use of a course website for online collaboration and discussion worked very well in the virtual setting during the pandemic. However, the use of Zoom was more limited (though the Zoom chat function was very useful for student participation given the larger class size) and could have been expanded to enable more frequent small-group collaboration or engagement with audiovisual materials.

The zoom discussions worked well, and lining up in the chat with comments was a good way to structure the discussions, as everybody was able to make their point. However, this also sometimes made the discussion a bit disjointed or circular, as people were returning to previous subjects with their comments after others had moved on (ie there was a lag due to the line).
professor adams did a great job with making sure the course remained interactive with discussions despite being online

I really liked the system where we put in the chat if we had a comment.  Sometimes I would get very anxious to put a comment in, but having the chat gave me time to think through what I wanted to say and it was a very casual space.  I also enjoyed the course blog format to organize our thoughts about the readings.

The blog and class discussions (particularly with the method of lining up in the chat) actually translated online quite well. This class worked well! I felt like our class became comfortable with one another and had great discussions!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Professor Adams is awesome, and the class is very interesting. I think it's a great course to see if you like sociology, because it covers a wide breadth of material.
Yes, it was a great class!
yes i would, it is a great opportunity to have sociological discussions and read interesting texts!
Yes definitely
If you are interested in exploring sociology, this is a great start!

Hell Yes! Awesome course which gives you the necessary background on modernity and civilization which is critical to understanding other sociological topics as it encompasses history, race, social dynamics, etc.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is a deep thinker. The texts are dense and at times very overwhelming, but if you read the blog post and pay attention in class then it will be an enjoyable time.

I would recommend this course to any student curious about what is meant by terms like "modernity" and how it is that we came to be "modern". Students should be ready to participate frequently in open discussions with others about the course readings, and to take the initiative to bring their own ideas and insights to the table. The course and its reading load also requires that students become efficient readers and read for quality and big ideas rather than quantity and tiny details.
I would. It was a bit out of my comfort zone, but I found it very interesting and would recommend the course, especially when it returns to an in-person format.
Absolutely! It's a lot of fun.
Yes
yes absolutely

Yes!!!  I had never taken a sociology course before this, but I really wanted to learn about how civilizations develop, different forms of government, and why people behave the way that they do.  I definitely got a glimpse of all of those things, and the robust class discussions were such a fun way to talk about topics that can seem intimidating on their own.  This class reminded me of how much I love reading, learning, and questioning the world around me, since it was a low-stress environment that was much more focused on discussion rather than grades.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Regardless of interest or discipline, this course exposes students to theories and thinkers everyone should have the opportunity to explore before leaving college! The course is accessible and engaging, but not elementary. It's truly the perfect intro course for anyone looking to deepen their understanding of sociology or just general social theory.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Mostly an online discussion.
twice weekly virtual class meetings
Virtual seminar
Discussion lecture with a course blog which we write in every week!
only live virtual lecture
N/A
